Variation Example: A foolish woman (man) sees cracks in the ground (house wall) & feels sorry for them. She greases them with the butter she is taking home (to the market).

Classifications: Other Objects or Animals sent to Go by Themselves
Variation Example: e.g. food (peas, flour) or animals (donkey, cow, pig, billy goat, hare). In the most popular version, a rabbit is sent to pay the rent. The foolish farmers hang a purse with money on him & often give him a tip in addition.

A married daughter visiting her mother will not stop a hog from rooting in the garden since she is a guest in the house. In some variants, a young wife, having been told how to behave “properly”, says “sir” to the dog as well as to the grandfather.

A numskull (drunken man) who is urinating outside misunderstands the noise of a flowing stream (well, falling rain) & thinks he has not finished yet. He keeps standing there for hours (more than a day).
A fool almost drowns when swimming. He swears never to go into the water again unless he has already learned how to swim.

A foolish woman buys several earthenware pots (dishes). She sets the pots on a fence. When they refuse to make room for the last pot, she breaks them all. (When the woman does not have enough room in her kitchen, she nails the crockery to the wall.)
A man tied to a floating log turns over so that his head is in the water & he is almost drowned. His comrades on the shore say, “He has not yet crossed the water & is already drying his legs”.

In the night, a man urinates outside through a door (wants to know what the weather is). Someone inside asks him how the weather is. He answers, “The sky is overcast & it smells like bread (there are no stars)”. He had opened the door to the pantry (cellar) by mistake.

Classifications: Getting the Calf's Head out of the Pot
Variation Example: A calf (camel, ox, sheep, dog) gets its head caught in a pot (jar). On advice of a fool, the calf’s head is cut off & then the pot is broken to get the head out.

Classifications: Child with Head Caught in Jar
Variation Example: A child (woman) gets her head caught in a jar (glass). A fool advises that the child’s head be cut off, but people prefer to break the jar. In some variants, a jar has to be broken because a foolish (greedy) woman (girl, child) cannot get her hand out of the narrow opening. She has made a fist to hold on to some contents of the jar.

A fool regrets that he did not eat (drink) the seventh cake (various other kinds of food or beverages) first, since that was the one that brought him satisfaction. In some cases, the eating is part of a contest.

Classifications: Tall Bridegroom Cannot Get into Church
Variation Example: A very tall bridegroom (bride) does not fit through the door of the church (her home). His foolish attendants argue whether to cut off his head or to pull down the door. A stranger hits him on his back & the bridegroom falls down. Now he can enter & the stranger gets a reward. In some variants, a man (woman) riding on a camel (horse) does not fit through a gate. The doorway is broken down. (A stranger advises him to dismount.)
A fool (apprentice) is sent out to get imaginary things, e.g. a left-handed monkey wrench, a bag of lies.

Classifications: Fools Go to Buy Good Weather
Variation Example: (storm, spring). They bring back a bumblebee, (hornet, butterfly, swarm of bees) in a box (sack). They become curious & open the box before they reach home. The good weather flies away.

A fool is to take two doves (crayfish, eels, bunches of grapes, gingerbread) in a basket to a farmer, along with an explanatory letter. On the way the doves escape (the fool eats the food). The farmer reads the letter & asks, “Where are the two doves that are in the letter?” – “They escaped from the basket. It’s lucky they are still in the letter.”In some variants a servant (girl) is sent to bring a basket of fruit along with a letter. On the way, he eats one of the fruits. The letter states how much fruit there was, so the recipient asks the servant what happened to one of the pieces. He replies that it was not in the basket. He is sent again on the same errand the following day. He hides the letter before he eats the fruit, because he thinks it can observe him.

Classifications: Jumping Into the River After Their Comrade
Variation Example: A Fool (fools) jump(s) into a river (sea, well) in order to cross the water (get imaginary sheep from the bottom, commit suicide). The fool’s comrades think that he wants them to follow, & all jump in & are drowned. In some variants, someone else makes the fools jump.

This tale exists chiefly in five different forms: (1) Instead of asking for his wages from a miser, a workman asks to be allowed to see the miser’s treasure. When asked why, he explains that this would give him the same satisfaction as it gives the miser. The latter repents & distributes his wealth among the poor. (2) A miser, whose treasure has been stolen, is advised to imagine that it is still intact; he will thus get as much pleasure from it as before. (3) A miser, wishing to take his gold to the grave with him, orders it to be melted so that he can drink it. Molten butter is substituted, & the miser is duped. (4) Even in grave danger or on his deathbed, the miser thinks about how to make or save money. (5) A miser is robbed while lying on his sickbed, or his hoard is found after his death.

Classifications: Miser Refuses to Give his Hand
Variation Example: A miser (clergyman, drunken man) falls into a well. Men hurry to rescue him (with a rope) & tell him to reach out his hand. He refuses. A wise man advises them not to ask for the hand of the miser but to propose him that he take their hands. The man seizes their hands & is rescued.
From figs (melons) which have been urinated on, a fool is to choose only the clean ones. In testing he eats them all.

This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A small water animal (e.g. turtle, crayfish, toad) has made an enemy of a big land animal (e.g. monkey, fox, lion, elephant) or of a man. The small animal, condemned to death, begs not to be drowned. Thereupon it is thrown into the water & escapes. (2) Numskulls find a crayfish. Because of its claws, the fools mistake the unknown animal for a tailor & put it on a piece of cloth which it is to cut up. The crayfish ruins the cloth. He is condemned to be drowned & is thrown into the water. When the animal swims with difficulty, one of the fools says, “See how it suffers”. (3) Numskulls set out pickled herrings in their pond & hope the fishes will propagate. When the fools drain the pond, they find a big eel which they suspect has devoured the herrings. As a punish ment the eel is to be drowned.

Classifications: The Crab is Thought to be the Devil
Variation Example: Numskulls find a crab (snail). They mistake the unknown animal for the devil (land-monster).
A rabbit (fox, jackal), who has stolen food, is caught & is to be punished. It pretends to be afraid of being thrown into a briar patch & thus induces its captor to do just that. The rabbit runs off.
Numskulls catch a mole which has devastated a meadow (field, garden). They consider how to punish the unknown animal & decide to bury it alive. The mole escapes.

Classifications: Throwing the Bird from a Cliff as Punishment
Variation Example: A captured bird (insect) which is to be punished for some misbehavior (e.g. stealing grain, stinging) pretends to be afraid of being thrown into an abyss. The man (animal) who caught the bird throws it down from a cliff (tower) & the bird flies away.

Classifications: The Wolf Taken for a Foal
Variation Example: The wolf is mistaken for a foal (shepherd’s dog, the luck). In the man’s absence the wolf eats a mare (parts of the flock, horse).

Classifications: The Bear Taken for a Dog
Variation Example: A bear is mistaken for a dog. In some variants, the dog is mistaken for a bear (wolf) (and killed).

Classifications: Trying to WAsh Black Animal White
Variation Example: A numskull tries to wash a black hen white because a customer wants to buy a white one. In some variants, numskulls try to wash a black bull white so that it will match the white cows. (They wash or paint their only bull in order to pretend that they own more than one.)

Classifications: The Man Who Wanted to Commit Suicide
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A fool has been told by his mother (wife) to perform various tasks. He fails & decides to kill himself. Remembering a pot full of food (beverage) which his mother said was poisoned, he eats (drinks) all of it & lies down as if dead. (2) A master (priest) tells his apprentice (novice) not to eat (drink) from a pot full of food (beverage) which he says is poisoned. The apprentice disregards the warning & nibbles at the attractive food. He defends himself by pretending that he wanted to commit suicide.

Classifications: The Man Takes Seriously the Prediction of Death
Variation Example: A passerby tells a numskull who is sawing the tree limb on which he is sitting that he will fall. When the fool falls, he believes the passerby to be a prophet & demands that he might tell him when he will die. The “prophet” tells him that he will die(1) when his donkey (horse) breaks wind three times, (2) when his hands & feet become cold, (3) when a red thread or the like comes from his body, (4) other signs. The prophesied event occurs & the fool thinks he is dead. When his pallbearers or passersby argue over which road to take, the fool sits up & advises them, “When I was alive, I took that one”.

A drunken man falls into an open grave & lies down to sleep. When he wakes up, he thinks he is dead. In some variants, a fool hides from soldiers (robbers) in an open grave. When they ask him what he is doing there he tells them that he is dead. (After the “dead man” is beaten by the soldiers, he returns home to warn his friends to avoid soldiers in the other world.)

A drunken man walking through a graveyard at night falls into an open grave. Someone finds him there (another drunk falls into the same grave), & the first man complains about how cold it is. “No wonder”, says the second man. “You pushed off the covers (earth)”; or, “you don’t have your shroud”.
doctor at the bedside of a sick man tells him that he is practically dead. The patient argues that he is not dead yet. His wife (someone else) tells him to be quiet, the doctor knows best.

Classifications: Mistaking Harmless Objects for Dangerous Ones
Variation Example: Fools mistake a butter churn for a dead man (the devil). They break it in two. In some variants, numskulls mistake a big tree for a snake (tree trunk for a devil or bear, big sausage for a dragon, bag full of rags for a bear, etc.). They try to kill the dangerous object with guns or spears.

Classifications: The Steamship Thought to be the Devil
Variation Example: Numskulls mistake a steamship for the devil. In some variants, a drunken man mistakes a train (bicycle) for the devil, refuses to get out of its way & is hurt.

Classifications: A White Mare Thought to be a Church
Variation Example: A short-sighted man (foolish woman, numskulls who have never seen a church but have been told that it is big & white) mistakes a white mare for a church.

This tale exists chiefly in five different forms: (1) A foolish farmhand who has been sent out to bring in cows (sheep) thinks that the rabbits running among them are part of the herd. (2) Numskulls mistake an earthworm for a snake (monster) or a frog for a lark (turtledove). (3) Numskulls (a hunter) mistake a donkey for a rabbit because of its long ears & kill it. (4) A fool mistakes a dungbeetle for a bee (5) Storks are mistaken for cows.
Four blind men feel an elephant’s leg, tail, ear, & body respectively, & conclude that the elephant is like a log, a rope, a fan, or something without beginning or end.

Classifications: Mistaking a Person (Animal, Object) for a Supernatural Being
Variation Example: Besides this general type, three specific versions can be distinguished: (1) A person (animal) who is hiding in a church (graveyard, hearse) is mistaken for a ghost (death). (2) A fool mistakes overflowing dough for a ghost. (3) A person in a haunted house shoots off all his toes because he mistakes them for ghosts.

Classifications: Pumpkin Sold as a Donkey's Egg
Variation Example: A numskull (numskulls) finds (buys) an unknown fruit (pumpkin, melon, etc.). He mistakes it for the egg of a donkey (mare, camel, etc.). When the fool tries to bring the “egg” home it falls down & scares a hidden rabbit (rabbit, fox, mouse). The fool thinks the fugitive is a young animal hatched from the egg. He pursues it or tries to attract it.
Misc. type. One person (animal, thing, process) is mistaken for another.
